For $X_1,...,X_n \sim N(\mu,\sigma^2)$:

$Z = \frac{\bar{X}-\mu}{\sqrt{\sigma^2/n}}\sim N(0,1)$

For sample mean $\bar{X} = \frac{1}{n}\sum^n_{i=1}X_i$:

$\bar{X} \sim N(\mu, \frac{\sigma^2}{n})$

For sample variance $S^2 = \frac{1}{n-1}\sum^n_{i=1}(X_i-\bar{X}^2)$ with degrees of freedom $d = (n-1)$:

$d\frac{S^2}{\sigma^2} \sim \chi^2_{d}$

or

$U/d \sim \chi^2_{d}$

where $U = S^2/\sigma^2$

When comparing two variances $S^2_1$ and $S^2_2$ with $d_1 = n_1 - 1$ and $d_2 = n_2 - 1$:

$F = \frac{(S^2_1/\sigma^2_1)/d_1}{(S^2_2/\sigma^2_2)/d_2} \sim F_{d_1,d_2}$

or

$F = \frac{U_1/d_1}{U_2/d_2} \sim F_{d_1,d_2}$

For ANOVA with $k$ groups and $n$ total observations:

$F = \frac{\text{between group variation}}{\text{within group variation}}$

where $d_1 = k - 1$ and $d_2 = n-k$.

When $n \rightarrow \infty$:

$F = \frac{U_1/d_1}{U_2/d_2} \rightarrow \frac{U_1}{d_1}$

and, therefore:

$F_{d_1,\infty} \rightarrow \chi^2_{d_1}/d_1$
